facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 24 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 27, 1966 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 90 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 27, 1966 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 90 of 1962.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered the referred question in the negative against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: from a judgment of the Calcutta High Court answering the following question referred to it under S. 66 1  of the Indian Income- tax Act, 1922, hereinafter called the Act in the negative and against the assessee

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company with registered office at Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a public limited companypany having its registered office at Calcutta. Its principal business companysists of manufacturing

facts.text: Assessee's principal business is manufacturing aluminium ingots, sheets and other products from aluminium.

anchor.surface_text: Its principal business companysists of manufacturing aluminium ingots, sheets and such other products from aluminium. There is another companypany known by the name of

facts.text: Aluminium Laboratories Limited, Montreal, Canada (Montreal Company) provided technical know-how, engineering services to assessee.

anchor.surface_text: There is another companypany known by the name of Aluminium Laboratories Limited, Montreal, in Canada, hereinafter called the Montreal Company, which provided the, assessee with technical know- how, engineering services etc.

facts.text: Agreement entered into on January 31, 1947 between Montreal Company and assessee.

anchor.surface_text: An agreement was entered into on January 31, 1947 between the Montreal Company and the assessee. The agreement provided for payment of a retainer fee

facts.text: Agreement provided for payment of retainer fee on annual basis, no stipulation for payment without tax deduction.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement provided for payment of a retainer fee on an annual basis. There was numbercondition or stipulation that the fee would be payable by the assessee without deduction of tax under the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Assessee credited Rs. 2,50,808/- to Montreal Company for seven years from accounting year ending September 30, 1944 to September 30, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee credited a total fee of Rs. 2,50,808/- in favour of the Montreal Company for a period of seven years between the accounting year ending, September 30, 1944 and September 30, 1950.

facts.text: In 1951, Income-tax Officer treated assessee in default under s.18(7) for tax on payments to Montreal Company under ss.18(3A), 18(3B), 18(3C), amount Rs. 1,24,199/-

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the Income-tax Officer treated the assessee as being in default under s. 18  7  of the Act in respect of the amount of tax which the assessee was liable to deduct from the payments made to the Montreal Company under the provisions of ss. 18 3-A , 18 3-B  and 18  3-C  of the Act. The amount of tax which was found to be payable by the assessee came to a total sum of Rs. 1,24,199/-

facts.text: Assessee wrote to Montreal Company for reimbursement of Rs. 1,24,199/-

anchor.surface_text: The assessee wrote to the Montreal Company asking for reimbursement of the said amount.

facts.text: Montreal Company refused reimbursement by letter dated August 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Montreal Company, however, refused to accept the assessees claim for re- imbursement by means of a letter dated August 3, 1954.

facts.text: Assessee wrote off Rs. 1,24,199/- during previous year ending December 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee wrote off the amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- during the relevant previous year ending on December 31, 1954.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who allowed the claim.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who allowed its claim.

facts.text: Department appealed to Tribunal, which held amount not deductible as expenditure or bad debt, restored ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The department preferred an appeal to the Tribunal which held that the amount in question was neither expenditure, incidental to the business number was it wholly and exclusively laid out for that purpose number was it claimable as a bad debt

facts.text: High Court held nexus to business but liability avoidable, not incidental, not bad debt, not under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was of the view that there was a nexus between payment and the business of the assessee inasmuch as it had an indirect bearing upon the technical aid which the assessee had obtained from the Montreal Company but was of the opinion that even if the payment had some companynection with the business it companyld number be said to be incidental to it

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We find numberreason or justification to interfere with the answer returned by the High Court with the result that the appeal fails and it is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Montreal Company stated in letter of August 3, 1954 that not contractually bound to meet Indian tax liability.

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised on behalf of the appellant is that the Montreal Company refused to reimburse it for the payment of the amount in question for the reasons stated in the letter dated August 3, 1954. It was stated in this letter that the Montreal Company was number companytractually bound to meet the obligation of Indian tax liability.

facts.text: Assessee claimed Rs. 1,24,199/- as bad debt under s.10(2)(xi).

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the assessee principally is two fold. It is maintained firstly that after the refusal of the Montreal Company in the matter of reimbursement the amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- was written off as a bad and irrecoverable debt.

facts.text: Supreme Court held amount not deductible as bad debt under s.10(2)(xi) as not incidental to business.

anchor.surface_text: Although it is true that the retainer fees were paid by the assessee to the Montreal Company for technical assistance which had a companynection with the business of the assessee but it is number possible to regard the amount which the assessee was bound to deduct from the total payment made to the Montreal Company under s. 18 3-B  of the Act

issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,24,199/- was deductible from the business income of the assessee either under Section 10(1) or 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the sum of Rs. 1,24,199/- was deductible from the business income of the assessee either under Section 10   1   or 10  2   xi  or 10  2   xv  of the Incometax Act ?

issues.text: Whether the amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- written off after refusal of reimbursement by the Montreal Company qualifies as a bad debt deductible under Section 10(2)(xi) of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the assessee principally is two fold. It is maintained firstly that after the refusal of the Montreal Company in the matter of reimbursement the amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- was written off as a bad and irrecoverable debt. It was, therefore deductible under s. 10 2   xi  of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the assessee could claim deduction of the amount under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Act as expenditure wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of its business?

arguments.claim: The amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- was written off as a bad and irrecoverable debt after refusal of reimbursement by Montreal Company and is deductible under s.10(2)(xi)

anchor.surface_text: The claim of the assessee principally is two fold. It is maintained firstly that after the refusal of the Montreal Company in the matter of reimbursement the amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- was written off as a bad and irrecoverable debt. It was, therefore deductible under s. 10 2   xi  of the Act.

arguments.claim: The assessee could claim deduction of Rs. 1,24,199/- under s.10(2)(xv) as wholly and exclusively laid out for business purposes

anchor.surface_text: Secondly the question is whether the assessee could claim deduction under s. 10 2   xv  of the Act. For that purpose the assessee had to establish that the amount in question had been wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of its business.

arguments.court_reasoning: Payment made under statutory obligation due to default cannot constitute expenditure wholly and exclusively for business

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised on behalf of the appellant is that the Montreal Company refused to reimburse it for the payment of the amount in question for the reasons stated in the letter dated August 3, 1954. It was stated in this letter that the Montreal Company was not contractually bound to meet the obligation of Indian tax liability.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: tions raised before us it is necessary to refer only to ss. 18 3-B  and 18  7  of the Act a they stood at the material time - S. 18 3-B -Any person re

arguments.court_reasoning: Fact accepted but does not make it business debt or expense

arguments.claim: Amount under s.10(2)(xv) must be wholly and exclusively for business; statutory default payment does not qualify
No provision in agreement creating contractual obligation to pay taxes under s.18(3B)

holdings.text: The assessee was bound under Section 18(3B) of the Act to deduct tax at source from the retainer fees paid to the non-resident Montreal Company.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that in the present case the assessee was bound under sub-section 3-B to deduct the sum chargeable under the provisions of the Act at the time of payment of the retainer fees to the Montreal Company. Under sub-section 7 if the assessee did not deduct the amount of tax as required under the section it was to be deemed to be in default in respect of the tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory provision requiring deduction at maximum rate on payments to non-residents.

holdings.text: There was no provision in the agreement creating a contractual obligation on the assessee to bear the Indian tax liability on payments to the Montreal Company.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of agreement text shows no stipulation for tax payment without deduction.

holdings.text: The amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- is not deductible as a bad debt under Section 10(2)(xi) because it is not a proper trading debt that springs directly from and is incidental to the business, but arose from non-compliance with Section 18(3B).

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore deductible under s. 10 2   xi  of the Act. In the section the debt certainly means something more than a mere advance. It is something which is related to business or results from it. To be claimable as a bad and irrecoverable debt it must first be shown as a proper debt. vide A. V. Thomas Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax 1

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bad debt must be incidental trading debt per settled law and precedent (A.V. Thomas); here statutory tax default creates non-business debt.

holdings.text: The amount of Rs. 1,24,199/- is not deductible under Section 10(2)(xv) as it was not wholly and exclusively laid out for the purpose of business, being a payment compelled by the assessee's default under the tax deduction provisions.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory default payment cannot satisfy 'wholly and exclusively' test even if business nexus; distinguishes Pannalal on facts.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 1,24,199/- was not deductible from the business income of the assessee under Section 10(1) or 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The payment which the assessee made to the income-tax authorities and which it failed to recover from the Montreal Company was more a matter of commercial expediency and proceeded out of motives of business relationship because the assessee was anxious  1  48 I.T. R. 67 at p. 75. not to annoy or offend the Montreal Company so as to avail of its continued technical assistance and advice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's negative answer based on above determinations that amount neither qualifies as bad debt nor business expenditure.

precedents.cited_proposition: a business or trading debt should spring directly from the carrying on of a business or trade and should be incidental to it and it cannot be just any loss sustained by the assessee even if it has some connection with his business
